Get the "up" direction that the camera would have if its orientation was set to the quaternion value.
The High Fidelity camera has axes x = right, y = up, -z = forward.
name: getUp

params.description: A quaternion representing an orientation.
params.name: orientation

returns.description: The y-axis rotated by orientation.

description:
Calculate the Euler angles for the quaternion, in degrees. (The "safe" in the name signifies that the angle results will
not be garbage even when the rotation is particularly difficult to decompose with pitches around +/-90 degrees.)
name: safeEulerAngles

params.description: A quaternion representing an orientation.
params.name: orientation

returns.description: A {@link Vec3} of Euler angles for the orientation, in degrees, the angles being the rotations about the x, y, and z axes.

examples:
<caption>Report the camera yaw.</caption>
var eulerAngles = Quat.safeEulerAngles(Camera.orientation);
print("Camera yaw: " + eulerAngles.y);

description: Generate a quaternion given an angle to rotate through and an axis to rotate about.
name: angleAxis

params.description: The angle to rotate through, in degrees.
params.name: angle

params.description: The unit axis to rotate about.
params.name: axis

returns.description: A quaternion that is a rotation through angle degrees about the axis. WARNING: This value is in degrees whereas the value returned by {@link Quat(0).angle|Quat.angle} is in radians.

examples:
<caption>Calculate a rotation of 90 degrees about the direction your camera is looking.</caption>
var rotation = Quat.angleAxis(90, Quat.getForward(Camera.orientation));

description: Get the rotation axis for a quaternion.
name: axis

params.description: The quaternion.
params.name: q

returns.description: The normalized rotation axis for q.

examples:
<caption>Get the rotation axis of a quaternion.</caption>
var forward = Quat.getForward(Camera.orientation);
var rotation = Quat.angleAxis(90, forward);
var axis = Quat.axis(rotation);
print("Forward: " + JSON.stringify(forward));
print("Axis: " + JSON.stringify(axis)); // Same value as forward.

description: Get the rotation angle for a quaternion.
name: angle

params.description: The quaternion.
params.name: q

returns.description: The rotation angle for q, in radians. WARNING: This value is in radians whereas the value used by {@link Quat(0).angleAxis|Quat.angleAxis} is in degrees.

examples:
<caption>Get the rotation angle of a quaternion.</caption>
var forward = Quat.getForward(Camera.orientation);
var rotation = Quat.angleAxis(90, forward);
var angle = Quat.angle(rotation);
print("Angle: " + angle * 180 / Math.PI);  // 90 degrees.

description:
Compute a spherical linear interpolation between two rotations, safely handling two rotations that are very similar.
See also, {@link Quat(0).slerp|Quat.slerp}.
name: mix

params.description: The beginning rotation.
params.name: q1

params.description: The ending rotation.
params.name: q2

params.description: The mixture coefficient between 0.0 and 1.0. Specifies the proportion of q2's value to return in favor of q1's value. A value of 0.0 returns q1's value; 1.0 returns q2s's value.
params.name: alpha

returns.description: A spherical linear interpolation between rotations q1 and q2.

examples:
<caption>Animate between one rotation and another.</caption>
var dt = amountOfTimeThatHasPassed;
var mixFactor = amountOfTimeThatHasPassed / TIME_TO_COMPLETE;
if (mixFactor > 1) {
    mixFactor = 1;
}
var newRotation = Quat.mix(startRotation, endRotation, mixFactor);

description:
Compute a spherical linear interpolation between two rotations, for rotations that are not very similar.
See also, {@link Quat(0).mix|Quat.mix}.
name: slerp

params.description: The beginning rotation.
params.name: q1

params.description: The ending rotation.
params.name: q2

params.description: The mixture coefficient between 0.0 and 1.0. Specifies the proportion of q2's value to return in favor of q1's value. A value of 0.0 returns q1's value; 1.0 returns q2s's value.
params.name: alpha

returns.description: A spherical linear interpolation between rotations q1 and q2.

description: Compute a spherical quadrangle interpolation between two rotations along a path oriented toward two other rotations. Equivalent to: Quat.slerp(Quat.slerp(q1, q2, alpha), Quat.slerp(s1, s2, alpha), 2 * alpha * (1.0 - alpha)).
name: squad

params.description: Initial rotation.
params.name: q1

params.description: Final rotation.
params.name: q2

params.description: First control point.
params.name: s1

params.description: Second control point.
params.name: s2

params.description: The mixture coefficient between 0.0 and 1.0. A value of 0.0 returns q1's value; 1.0 returns q2s's value.
params.name: alpha

returns.description: A spherical quadrangle interpolation between rotations q1 and q2 using control points s1 and s2.

description:
Calculate the dot product of two quaternions. The closer the quaternions are to each other the more non-zero the value is
(either positive or negative). Identical unit rotations have a dot product of +/- 1.
name: dot

params.description: The first quaternion.
params.name: q1

params.description: The second quaternion.
params.name: q2

returns.description: The dot product of q1 and q2.

examples:
<caption>Testing unit quaternions for equality.</caption>
var q1 = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 0, 0);
var q2 = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 0, 0);
print(Quat.equal(q1, q2)); // true
var q3 = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 0, 359.95);
print(Quat.equal(q1, q3)); // false

var dot = Quat.dot(q1, q3);
print(dot); // -0.9999999403953552
var equal = Math.abs(1 - Math.abs(dot)) < 0.000001;
print(equal); // true

description: Print to the program log a text label followed by a quaternion's pitch, yaw, and roll Euler angles.
name: print

params.description: The label to print.
params.name: label

params.description: The quaternion to print.
params.name: q

params.description: If true the angle values are printed in degrees, otherwise they are printed in radians.
params.name: asDegrees

examples:
<caption>Two ways of printing a label plus a quaternion's Euler angles.</caption>
var quaternion = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 45, 0);

// Quaternion: dvec3(0.000000, 45.000004, 0.000000)
Quat.print("Quaternion:", quaternion,  true);

// Quaternion: {"x":0,"y":45.000003814697266,"z":0}
print("Quaternion: " + JSON.stringify(Quat.safeEulerAngles(quaternion)));

description: Test whether two quaternions are equal. Note: The quaternions must be exactly equal in order for true to be returned; it is often better to use {@link Quat(0).dot|Quat.dot} and test for closeness to +/-1.
name: equal

params.description: The first quaternion.
params.name: q1

params.description: The second quaternion.
params.name: q2

returns.description: true if the quaternions are equal, otherwise false.

examples:
<caption>Testing unit quaternions for equality.</caption>
var q1 = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 0, 0);
var q2 = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 0, 0);
print(Quat.equal(q1, q2)); // true
var q3 = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(0, 0, 359.95);
print(Quat.equal(q1, q3)); // false

var dot = Quat.dot(q1, q3);
print(dot); // -0.9999999403953552
var equal = Math.abs(1 - Math.abs(dot)) < 0.000001;
print(equal); // true

description:
Cancels out the roll and pitch component of a quaternion so that its completely horizontal with a yaw pointing in the 
given quaternion's direction.
name: cancelOutRollAndPitch

params.description: A quaternion representing an orientation.
params.name: orientation

returns.description: orientation with its roll and pitch canceled out.

examples:
<caption>Two ways of calculating a camera orientation in the x-z plane with a yaw pointing in the direction of
    a given quaternion.</caption>
var quaternion = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(10, 20, 30);

var noRollOrPitch = Quat.cancelOutRollAndPitch(quaternion);
Quat.print("", noRollOrPitch, true); // dvec3(0.000000, 22.245995, 0.000000)

var front = Quat.getFront(quaternion);
var lookAt = Quat.lookAtSimple(Vec3.ZERO, { x: front.x, y: 0, z: front.z });
Quat.print("", lookAt, true); // dvec3(0.000000, 22.245996, 0.000000)

description: Cancels out the roll component of a quaternion so that its horizontal axis is level.
name: cancelOutRoll

params.description: A quaternion representing an orientation.
params.name: orientation

returns.description: orientation with its roll canceled out.

examples:
<caption>Two ways of calculating a camera orientation that points in the direction of a given quaternion but
    keeps the camera's horizontal axis level.</caption>
var quaternion = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(10, 20, 30);

var noRoll = Quat.cancelOutRoll(quaternion);
Quat.print("", noRoll, true); // dvec3(-1.033004, 22.245996, -0.000000)

var front = Quat.getFront(quaternion);
var lookAt = Quat.lookAtSimple(Vec3.ZERO, front);
Quat.print("", lookAt, true); // dvec3(-1.033004, 22.245996, -0.000000)

description: Supported Script Types: Interface Scripts • Client Entity Scripts • Avatar Scripts

Plays or "injects" the content of an audio file.

Create using {@link Audio} API methods.

Supported Script Types: Interface Scripts • Client Entity Scripts • Avatar Scripts • Server Entity Scripts • Assignment Client Scripts
name: AudioInjector

properties.description: true if the audio is currently playing, otherwise false. Read-only.
properties.name: playing

properties.description: The loudness in the last frame of audio, range 0.0 – 1.0. Read-only.
properties.name: loudness

properties.description: Configures how the injector plays the audio.
properties.name: options

description: Stops current playback, if any, and starts playing from the beginning.
name: restart

description: Stops audio playback.
name: stop
examples:
<caption>Stop playing a sound before it finishes.</caption>
var sound = SoundCache.getSound(Script.resourcesPath() + "sounds/sample.wav");
var injector;
var injectorOptions = {
    position: MyAvatar.position
};

Script.setTimeout(function () { // Give the sound time to load.
    injector = Audio.playSound(sound, injectorOptions);
}, 1000);

Script.setTimeout(function () {
    injector.stop();
}, 2000);

description: Gets the current configuration of the audio injector.
name: getOptions

returns.description: Configuration of how the injector plays the audio.

description: Configures how the injector plays the audio.
name: setOptions

params.description: Configuration of how the injector plays the audio.
params.name: options

description: Gets the loudness of the most recent frame of audio played.
name: getLoudness

returns.description: The loudness of the most recent frame of audio played, range 0.0 – 1.0.

description: Gets whether or not the audio is currently playing.
name: isPlaying

returns.description: true if the audio is currently playing, otherwise false.

examples:
<caption>See if a sound is playing.</caption>
var sound = SoundCache.getSound(Script.resourcesPath() + "sounds/sample.wav");
var injector;
var injectorOptions = {
    position: MyAvatar.position
};

Script.setTimeout(function () { // Give the sound time to load.
    injector = Audio.playSound(sound, injectorOptions);
}, 1000);

Script.setTimeout(function () {
    print("Sound is playing: " + injector.isPlaying());
}, 2000);

description: Triggered when the audio has finished playing.
name: finished
examples:
<caption>Report when a sound has finished playing.</caption>
var sound = SoundCache.getSound(Script.resourcesPath() + "sounds/sample.wav");
var injector;
var injectorOptions = {
    position: MyAvatar.position
};

Script.setTimeout(function () { // Give the sound time to load.
    injector = Audio.playSound(sound, injectorOptions);
    injector.finished.connect(function () {
        print("Finished playing sound");
    });
}, 1000);

description:
Triggered when the script starts for a user.

Note: Can only be connected to via this.preload = function (...) { ... } in the entity script.

Available in:Client Entity ScriptsServer Entity Scripts
name: preload

params.description: The ID of the entity that the script is running in.
params.name: entityID

examples:
<caption>Get the ID of the entity that a client entity script is running in.</caption>
var entityScript = (function () {
    this.entityID = Uuid.NULL;

    this.preload = function (entityID) {
        this.entityID = entityID;
        print("Entity ID: " + this.entityID);
    };
);

var entityID = Entities.addEntity({
    type: "Box",
    position: Vec3.sum(MyAvatar.position, Vec3.multiplyQbyV(MyAvatar.orientation, { x: 0, y: 0, z: -5 })),
    dimensions: { x: 0.5, y: 0.5, z: 0.5 },
    color: { red: 255, green: 0, blue: 0 },
    script: "(" + entityScript + ")",  // Could host the script on a Web server instead.
    lifetime: 300  // Delete after 5 minutes.
});

description: Supported Script Types: Interface Scripts • Client Entity Scripts • Avatar Scripts • Server Entity Scripts • Assignment Client Scripts

description: Start a new Interface or entity script.
name: load

params.description: The URL of the script to load. Can be relative to the current script.
params.name: filename

examples:
<caption>Load a script from another script.</caption>
// First file: scriptA.js
print("This is script A");

// Second file: scriptB.js
print("This is script B");
Script.load("scriptA.js");

// If you run scriptB.js you should see both scripts in the running scripts list.

description:
Include JavaScript from other files in the current script. If a callback is specified the files are loaded and included 
asynchronously, otherwise they are included synchronously (i.e., script execution blocks while the files are included).
name: include

params.description: The URLs of the scripts to include. Each can be relative to the current script.
params.name: filenames

params.description:
The function to call back when the scripts have been included. Can be an in-line 
function or the name of a function.
params.name: callback

description:
Include JavaScript from another file in the current script. If a callback is specified the file is loaded and included 
asynchronously, otherwise it is included synchronously (i.e., script execution blocks while the file is included).
name: include

params.description: The URL of the script to include. Can be relative to the current script.
params.name: filename

params.description:
The function to call back when the script has been included. Can be an in-line 
function or the name of a function.
params.name: callback

examples:
<caption>Include a script file asynchronously.</caption>
// First file: scriptA.js
print("This is script A");

// Second file: scriptB.js
print("This is script B");
Script.include("scriptA.js", function () {
    print("Script A has been included");
});

// If you run scriptB.js you should see only scriptB.js in the running scripts list.
// And you should see the following output:
// This is script B
// This is script A
// Script A has been included

description:
A UUID (Universally Unique IDentifier) is used to uniquely identify entities, avatars, and the like. It is represented in JavaScript as a string in the format, {nnnnnnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnnnnnnnnnn}, where the "n"s are hexadecimal digits.

Supported Script Types: Interface Scripts • Client Entity Scripts • Avatar Scripts • Server Entity Scripts • Assignment Client Scripts
name: Uuid

description: Generates a UUID from a string representation of the UUID.
name: fromString

params.description: A string representation of a UUID. The curly braces are optional.
params.name: string

returns.description: A UUID if the given string is valid, null otherwise.

examples:
<caption>Valid and invalid parameters.</caption>
var uuid = Uuid.fromString("{527c27ea-6d7b-4b47-9ae2-b3051d50d2cd}");
print(uuid); // {527c27ea-6d7b-4b47-9ae2-b3051d50d2cd}

uuid = Uuid.fromString("527c27ea-6d7b-4b47-9ae2-b3051d50d2cd");
print(uuid); // {527c27ea-6d7b-4b47-9ae2-b3051d50d2cd}

uuid = Uuid.fromString("527c27ea");
print(uuid); // null

description:
Generates a string representation of a UUID. However, because UUIDs are represented in JavaScript as strings, this is in
effect a no-op.
name: toString

params.description: The UUID to generate a string from.
params.name: id

returns.description: - A string representation of the UUID.

description: Generate a new UUID.
name: generate

returns.description: A new UUID.

examples:
<caption>Generate a new UUID and reports its JavaScript type.</caption>
var uuid = Uuid.generate();
print(uuid);        // {nnnnnnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnnnnnnnnnn}
print(typeof uuid); // string

description: Test whether two given UUIDs are equal.
name: isEqual

params.description: The first UUID to compare.
params.name: idA

params.description: The second UUID to compare.
params.name: idB

returns.description: true if the two UUIDs are equal, otherwise false.

examples: Demonstrate true and false cases. var uuidA = Uuid.generate(); var uuidB = Uuid.generate(); print(Uuid.isEqual(uuidA, uuidB)); // false uuidB = uuidA; print(Uuid.isEqual(uuidA, uuidB)); // true

description: Test whether a given UUID is null.
name: isNull

params.description: The UUID to test.
params.name: id

returns.description: true if the UUID equals Uuid.NULL or is null, otherwise false.

examples: Demonstrate true and false cases. var uuid; // undefined print(Uuid.isNull(uuid)); // false uuid = Uuid.generate(); print(Uuid.isNull(uuid)); // false uuid = Uuid.NULL; print(Uuid.isNull(uuid)); // true uuid = null; print(Uuid.isNull(uuid)); // true

description: Print to the program log a text label followed by the UUID value.
name: print

params.description: The label to print.
params.name: label

params.description: The UUID to print.
params.name: id

examples:
<caption>Two ways of printing a label plus UUID.</caption>
var uuid = Uuid.generate();
Uuid.print("Generated UUID:", uuid); // Generated UUID: {nnnnnnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnnnnnnnnnn}
print("Generated UUID: " + uuid);    // Generated UUID: {nnnnnnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnn-nnnnnnnnnnnn}

description: A display or device touch event.
name: TouchEvent

properties.description: Integer x-coordinate of the average position of the touch events.
properties.name: x

properties.description: Integer y-coordinate of the average position of the touch events.
properties.name: y

properties.description: true if the touch point has just been pressed, otherwise false.
properties.name: isPressed

properties.description: true if the touch point has moved, otherwise false.
properties.name: isMoved

properties.description: true if the touch point has not moved, otherwise false.
properties.name: isStationary

properties.description: true if the touch point has just been released, otherwise false.
properties.name: isReleased

properties.description: true if the Shift key was pressed when the event was generated, otherwise false.
properties.name: isShifted

properties.description: true if the "meta" key was pressed when the event was generated, otherwise false. On Windows the "meta" key is the Windows key; on OSX it is the Control (Splat) key.
properties.name: isMeta

properties.description: true if the "control" key was pressed when the event was generated, otherwise false. On Windows the "control" key is the Ctrl key; on OSX it is the Command key.
properties.name: isControl

properties.description: true if the Alt key was pressed when the event was generated, otherwise false.
properties.name: isAlt

properties.description: Integer number of touch points.
properties.name: touchPoints

properties.description: The coordinates of the touch points.
properties.name: points

properties.description: The radius of a circle centered on their average position that encompasses the touch points.
properties.name: radius

properties.description: true if the radius has reduced since the most recent touch event with a different radius value, otherwise false.
properties.name: isPinching

properties.description: true if the radius has increased since the most recent touch event with a different radius value, otherwise false.
properties.name: isPinchOpening

properties.description: An angle calculated from the touch points, in degrees.
properties.name: angle

properties.description: The change in the angle value since the previous touch event, in degrees, if the number of touch points is the same, otherwise 0.0.
properties.name: deltaAngle

properties.description: The angles of each touch point about the center of all the touch points, in degrees.
properties.name: angles

properties.description: true if the angle of the touch event has changed since the previous touch event and the number of touch points is the same, otherwise false.
properties.name: isRotating

properties.description: "clockwise" or "counterClockwise" if the angle of the touch event has changed since the previous touch event and the number of touch points is the same, otherwise "none".
properties.name: rotating

examples:
<caption>Report the TouchEvent details when a touch event starts.</caption>
Controller.touchBeginEvent.connect(function (event) {
    print(JSON.stringify(event));
});

description:
Kick/ban another user. Removes them from the server and prevents them from returning. Bans by either user name (if 
available) or machine fingerprint otherwise. This will only do anything if you're an admin of the domain you're in.

description:
Mutes another user's microphone for everyone. Not permanent; the silenced user can unmute themselves with the UNMUTE 
button in their HUD. This will only do anything if you're an admin of the domain you're in.

params.name: nodeID

Request the user name and machine fingerprint associated with the given UUID. The user name will be returned in a

description:
The Vec3 API facilities for generating and manipulating 3-dimensional vectors. High Fidelity uses a right-handed Cartesian coordinate system where the y-axis is the "up" and the negative z-axis is the "front" direction.

Supported Script Types: Interface Scripts • Client Entity Scripts • Avatar Scripts • Server Entity Scripts • Assignment Client Scripts
name: Vec3

properties.description: { x: 1, y: 0, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the x-axis direction. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_X

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 1, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the y-axis direction. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_Y

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 0, z: 1 } : Unit vector in the z-axis direction. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_Z

properties.description: { x: -1, y: 0, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the negative x-axis direction. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_NEG_X

properties.description: { x: 0, y: -1, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the negative y-axis direction. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_NEG_Y

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 0, z: -1 } : Unit vector in the negative z-axis direction. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_NEG_Z

properties.description: { x: 0.707107, y: 0.707107, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the direction of the diagonal between the x and y axes. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_XY

properties.description: { x: 0.707107, y: 0, z: 0.707107 } : Unit vector in the direction of the diagonal between the x and z axes. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_XZ

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 0.707107, z: 0.707107 } : Unit vector in the direction of the diagonal between the y and z axes. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_YZ

properties.description: { x: 0.577350, y: 0.577350, z: 0.577350 } : Unit vector in the direction of the diagonal between the x, y, and z axes. Read-only.
properties.name: UNIT_XYZ

properties.description: { x: 3.402823e+38, y: 3.402823e+38, z: 3.402823e+38 } : Vector with all axis values set to the maximum floating point value. Read-only.
properties.name: FLOAT_MAX

properties.description: { x: -3.402823e+38, y: -3.402823e+38, z: -3.402823e+38 } : Vector with all axis values set to the negative of the maximum floating point value. Read-only.
properties.name: FLOAT_MIN

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 0, z: 0 } : Vector with all axis values set to 0. Read-only.
properties.name: ZERO

properties.description: { x: 1, y: 1, z: 1 } : Vector with all axis values set to 1. Read-only.
properties.name: ONE

properties.description: { x: 2, y: 2, z: 2 } : Vector with all axis values set to 2. Read-only.
properties.name: TWO

properties.description: { x: 0.5, y: 0.5, z: 0.5 } : Vector with all axis values set to 0.5. Read-only.
properties.name: HALF

properties.description: { x: 1, y: 0, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the "right" direction. Synonym for UNIT_X. Read-only.
properties.name: RIGHT

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 1, z: 0 } : Unit vector in the "up" direction. Synonym for UNIT_Y. Read-only.
properties.name: UP

properties.description: { x: 0, y: 0, z: -1 } : Unit vector in the "front" direction. Synonym for UNIT_NEG_Z. Read-only.
properties.name: FRONT

description: Calculate the reflection of a vector in a plane.
name: reflect

params.description: The vector to reflect.
params.name: v

params.description: The normal of the plane.
params.name: normal

returns.description: The vector reflected in the plane given by the normal.

examples:
<caption>Reflect a vector in the x-z plane.</caption>
var v = { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 };
var normal = Vec3.UNIT_Y;
var reflected = Vec3.reflect(v, normal);
print(JSON.stringify(reflected));  // {"x":1,"y":-2,"z":3}

description: Calculate the cross product of two vectors.
name: cross

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: The cross product of v1 and v2.

examples:
<caption>The cross product of x and y unit vectors is the z unit vector.</caption>
var v1 = { x: 1, y: 0, z: 0 };
var v2 = { x: 0, y: 1, z: 0 };
var crossProduct = Vec3.cross(v1, v2);
print(JSON.stringify(crossProduct)); // {"x":0,"y":0,"z":1}

description: Calculate the dot product of two vectors.
name: dot

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: The dot product of v1 and v2.

examples: The dot product of vectors at right angles is 0. var v1 = { x: 1, y: 0, z: 0 }; var v2 = { x: 0, y: 1, z: 0 }; var dotProduct = Vec3.dot(v1, v2); print(dotProduct); // 0

description: Multiply a vector by a scale factor.
name: multiply

params.description: The vector.
params.name: v

params.description: The scale factor.
params.name: scale

returns.description: The vector with each ordinate value multiplied by the scale.

description: Multiply a vector by a scale factor.
name: multiply

params.description: The scale factor.
params.name: scale

params.description: The vector.
params.name: v

returns.description: The vector with each ordinate value multiplied by the scale.

description: Multiply two vectors.
name: multiplyVbyV

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: A vector formed by multiplying the ordinates of two vectors: { x: v1.x * v2.x, y: v1.y * v2.y, z: v1.z * v2.z }.

examples:
<caption>Multiply two vectors.</caption>
var v1 = { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 };
var v2 = { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 };
var multiplied = Vec3.multiplyVbyV(v1, v2);
print(JSON.stringify(multiplied));  // {"x":1,"y":4,"z":9}

description: Rotate a vector.
name: multiplyQbyV

params.description: The rotation to apply.
params.name: q

params.description: The vector to rotate.
params.name: v

returns.description: v rotated by q.

examples:
<caption>Rotate the negative z-axis by 90 degrees about the x-axis.</caption>
var v = Vec3.UNIT_NEG_Z;
var q = Quat.fromPitchYawRollDegrees(90, 0, 0);
var result = Vec3.multiplyQbyV(q, v);
print(JSON.stringify(result));  // {"x":0,"y":1.000,"z":1.19e-7}

description: Calculate the sum of two vectors.
name: sum

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: The sum of the two vectors.

description: Calculate one vector subtracted from another.
name: subtract

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: The second vector subtracted from the first.

description: Calculate the length of a vector
name: length

params.description: The vector.
params.name: v

returns.description: The length of the vector.

description: Calculate the distance between two points.
name: distance

params.description: The first point.
params.name: p1

params.description: The second point.
params.name: p2

returns.description: The distance between the two points.

examples:
<caption>The distance between two points is aways positive.</caption>
var p1 = { x: 0, y: 0, z: 0 };
var p2 = { x: 0, y: 0, z: 10 };
var distance = Vec3.distance(p1, p2);
print(distance); // 10

p2 = { x: 0, y: 0, z: -10 };
distance = Vec3.distance(p1, p2);
print(distance); // 10

description: Calculate the angle of rotation from one vector onto another, with the sign depending on a reference vector.
name: orientedAngle

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

params.description: Reference vector.
params.name: ref

returns.description:
The angle of rotation from the first vector to the second, in degrees, with a positive sign if the 
rotation axis aligns with the reference vector (has a positive dot product) otherwise a negative sign.

examples: Compare Vec3.angle() and Vec3.orientedAngle(). var v1 = { x: 5, y: 0, z: 0 }; var v2 = { x: 5, y: 0, z: 5 }; var angle = Vec3.getAngle(v1, v2); print(angle * 180 / Math.PI); // 45 print(Vec3.orientedAngle(v1, v2, Vec3.UNIT_Y)); // -45 print(Vec3.orientedAngle(v1, v2, Vec3.UNIT_NEG_Y)); // 45 print(Vec3.orientedAngle(v1, v2, { x: 1, y: 2, z: -1 })); // -45 print(Vec3.orientedAngle(v1, v2, { x: 1, y: -2, z: -1 })); // 45

description: Normalize a vector so that its length is 1.
name: normalize

params.description: The vector to normalize.
params.name: v

returns.description: The vector normalized to have a length of 1.

examples:
<caption>Normalize a vector.</caption>
var v = { x: 10, y: 10, z: 0 };
var normalized = Vec3.normalize(v);
print(JSON.stringify(normalized));  // {"x":0.7071,"y":0.7071,"z":0}
print(Vec3.length(normalized));  // 1

description: Calculate a linear interpolation between two vectors.
name: mix

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

params.description: The interpolation factor in the range 0.0 to 1.0.
params.name: factor

returns.description: The linear interpolation between the two vectors: (1 - factor) * v1 + factor * v2.

examples:
<caption>Linear interpolation between two vectors.</caption>
var v1 = { x: 10, y: 0, z: 0 };
var v2 = { x: 0, y: 10, z: 0 };
var interpolated = Vec3.mix(v1, v2, 0.75);  // 1/4 of v1 and 3/4 of v2.
print(JSON.stringify(interpolated));  // {"x":2.5,"y":7.5","z":0}

description: Print to the program log a text label followed by a vector value.
name: print

params.description: The label to print.
params.name: label

params.description: The vector value to print.
params.name: v

examples:
<caption>Two ways of printing a label and vector value.</caption>
var v = { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 };
Vec3.print("Vector: ", v);  // dvec3(1.000000, 2.000000, 3.000000)
print("Vector: " + JSON.stringify(v));  // {"x":1,"y":2,"z":3}

description: Test whether two vectors are equal. Note: The vectors must be exactly equal in order for true to be returned; it is often better to use {@link Vec3(0).withinEpsilon|withinEpsilon}.
name: equal

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: true if the two vectors are exactly equal, otherwise false.

examples:
<caption> Vectors are only equal if exactly the same.</caption>
var v1 = { x: 10, y: 10, z: 10 };
var v2 = { x: 10, y: 10, z: 10 };
var equal = Vec3.equal(v1, v2);
print(equal);  // true

v2 = { x: 10, y: 10, z: 10.0005 };
equal = Vec3.equal(v1, v2);
print(equal);  // false

description: Test whether two vectors are equal within a tolerance. Note: It is often better to use this function than {@link Vec3(0).equal|equal}.
name: withinEpsilon

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

params.description: The maximum distance between the two vectors.
params.name: epsilon

returns.description: true if the distance between the points represented by the vectors is less than or equal to the epsilon, otherwise false.

examples:
<caption>Testing vectors for near equality.</caption>
var v1 = { x: 10, y: 10, z: 10 };
var v2 = { x: 10, y: 10, z: 10.0005 };
var equal = Vec3.equal(v1, v2);
print(equal);  // false

equal = Vec3.withinEpsilon(v1, v2, 0.001);
print(equal);  // true

description: Calculate polar coordinates (elevation, azimuth, radius) that transform the unit z-axis vector onto a point.
name: toPolar

params.description: The point to calculate the polar coordinates for.
params.name: p

returns.description: Vector of polar coordinates for the point: x elevation rotation about the x-axis in radians, y azimuth rotation about the y-axis in radians, and z scale.

examples:
<caption>Polar coordinates for a point.</caption>
var v = { x: 5, y: 2.5, z: 5 };
var polar = Vec3.toPolar(v);
print("Elevation: " + polar.x * 180 / Math.PI);  // -19.471
print("Azimuth: " + polar.y * 180 / Math.PI);  // 45
print("Radius: " + polar.z);  // 7.5

description: Calculate the coordinates of a point from polar coordinate transformation of the unit z-axis vector.
name: fromPolar

params.description: The polar coordinates of a point: x elevation rotation about the x-axis in radians, y azimuth rotation about the y-axis in radians, and z scale.
params.name: polar

returns.description: The coordinates of the point.

examples:
<caption>Polar coordinates to Cartesian.</caption>
var polar = { x: -19.471 * Math.PI / 180, y: 45 * Math.PI / 180, z: 7.5 };
var p = Vec3.fromPolar(polar);
print(JSON.stringify(p));  // {"x":5,"y":2.5,"z":5}

description:
Calculate the unit vector corresponding to polar coordinates elevation and azimuth transformation of the unit z-axis 
vector.
name: fromPolar

params.description: Rotation about the x-axis, in radians.
params.name: elevation

params.description: Rotation about the y-axis, in radians.
params.name: azimuth

returns.description: Unit vector for the direction specified by elevation and azimuth.

examples:
<caption>Polar coordinates to Cartesian.</caption>
var elevation = -19.471 * Math.PI / 180;
var rotation = 45 * Math.PI / 180;
var p = Vec3.fromPolar(elevation, rotation);
print(JSON.stringify(p));  // {"x":0.667,"y":0.333,"z":0.667}

p = Vec3.multiply(7.5, p);
print(JSON.stringify(p));  // {"x":5,"y":2.5,"z":5}

description: Calculate the angle between two vectors.
name: getAngle

params.description: The first vector.
params.name: v1

params.description: The second vector.
params.name: v2

returns.description: The angle between the two vectors, in radians.

examples:
<caption>Calculate the angle between two vectors.</caption>
var v1 = { x: 10, y: 0, z: 0 };
var v2 = { x: 0, y: 0, z: 10 };
var angle = Vec3.getAngle(v1, v2);
print(angle * 180 / Math.PI);  // 90

description:

description:
Helper functions to render ephemeral debug markers and lines. DebugDraw markers and lines are only visible locally, they are not visible by other users.

Supported Script Types: Interface Scripts • Client Entity Scripts • Avatar Scripts • Server Entity Scripts • Assignment Client Scripts

params.description: start position of line in world space.

Adds a debug marker to the world. This marker will be drawn every frame until it is removed with DebugDraw.removeMarker.
This can be called repeatedly to change the position of the marker.

description:
An entity may collide with the following types of items:

ValueDescription
1Static entities — non-dynamic entities with no velocity.
2Dynamic entities — entities that have their dynamic property set to true.
4Kinematic entities — non-dynamic entities with velocity.
8My avatar.
16Other avatars.

The values for the collision types that are enabled are added together to give the CollisionMask value. For example, a value of 31 means that an entity will collide with all item types.
name: CollisionMask

description:
A KeyboardModifiers value is used to specify which modifier keys on the keyboard are pressed. The value is the sum (bitwise OR) of the relevant combination of values from the following table:

KeyHexadecimal valueDecimal valueDescription
Shift0x0200000033554432 A Shift key on the keyboard is pressed.
Control0x0400000067108864 A control key on the keyboard is pressed. On Windows the "control" key is the Ctrl key; on OSX it is the Command key.
Alt0x08000000134217728 An Alt key on the keyboard is pressed.
Meta0x10000000268435456 A meta key on the keyboard is pressed. On Windows the "meta" key is the Windows key; on OSX it is the Control (Splat) key.
Keypad0x20000000536870912 A keypad button is pressed.
Group0x400000001073741824 X11 operating system only: An AltGr / Mode_switch key on the keyboard is pressed.
name: KeyboardModifiers

description: A 2-dimensional vector.
name: Vec2

properties.description: X-coordinate of the vector. Synonyms: u.
properties.name: x

properties.description: Y-coordinate of the vector. Synonyms: v.
properties.name: y

examples:
<caption>Vec2s can be set in multiple ways and modified with their aliases, but still stringify in the same way</caption>
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { materialMappingPos: { x: 0.1, y: 0.2 }});          // { x: 0.1, y: 0.2 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { materialMappingPos: { u: 0.3, v: 0.4 }});          // { x: 0.3, y: 0.4 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { materialMappingPos: [0.5, 0.6] });                 // { x: 0.5, y: 0.6 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { materialMappingPos: 0.7 });                        // { x: 0.7, y: 0.7 }
var color = Entities.getEntityProperties(<id>).materialMappingPos;             // { x: 0.7, y: 0.7 }
color.v = 0.8;                                                                 // { x: 0.7, y: 0.8 }

description: A 3-dimensional vector. See also the {@link Vec3(0)|Vec3} object.
name: Vec3

properties.description: X-coordinate of the vector. Synonyms: r, red.
properties.name: x

properties.description: Y-coordinate of the vector. Synonyms: g, green.
properties.name: y

properties.description: Z-coordinate of the vector. Synonyms: b, blue.
properties.name: z

examples:
<caption>Vec3s can be set in multiple ways and modified with their aliases, but still stringify in the same way</caption>
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }});                 // { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: { r: 4, g: 5, b: 6 }});                 // { x: 4, y: 5, z: 6 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: { red: 7, green: 8, blue: 9 }});        // { x: 7, y: 8, z: 9 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: [10, 11, 12] });                        // { x: 10, y: 11, z: 12 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: 13 });                                  // { x: 13, y: 13, z: 13 }
var position = Entities.getEntityProperties(<id>).position;                   // { x: 13, y: 13, z: 13 }
position.g = 14;                                                              // { x: 13, y: 14, z: 13 }
position.blue = 15;                                                           // { x: 13, y: 14, z: 15 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: "red"});                                // { x: 255, y: 0, z: 0 }
Entities.editEntity(<id>, { position: "#00FF00"});                            // { x: 0, y: 255, z: 0 }

description:
Camera modes affect the position of the camera and the controls for camera movement. The camera can be in one of the following modes:

Mode String Description
First Person "first person" The camera is positioned such that you have the same view as your avatar. The camera moves and rotates with your avatar.
Third Person "third person" The camera is positioned such that you have a view from just behind your avatar. The camera moves and rotates with your avatar.
Mirror "mirror" The camera is positioned such that you are looking directly at your avatar. The camera moves and rotates with your avatar.
Independent "independent" The camera's position and orientation don't change with your avatar movement. Instead, they can be set via scripting.
Entity "entity" The camera's position and orientation are set to be the same as a specified entity's, and move with the entity as it moves.
name: Mode

description: Computes a {@link PickRay} based on the current camera configuration and the specified x, y position on the screen. The {@link PickRay} can be used in functions such as {@link Entities.findRayIntersection} and {@link Overlays.findRayIntersection}.
name: computePickRay

params.description: X-coordinate on screen.
params.name: x

params.description: Y-coordinate on screen.
params.name: y

returns.description: The computed {@link PickRay}.

examples:
<caption>Use a PickRay to detect mouse clicks on entities.</caption>
function onMousePressEvent(event) {
    var pickRay = Camera.computePickRay(event.x, event.y);
    var intersection = Entities.findRayIntersection(pickRay);
    if (intersection.intersects) {
        print("You clicked on entity " + intersection.entityID);
    }
}

Controller.mousePressEvent.connect(onMousePressEvent);

description: Rotates the camera to look at the specified position. Only works if the camera is in independent mode.
name: lookAt

params.description: The position to look at.
params.name: position

examples:
<caption>Rotate your camera to look at entities as you click on them with your mouse.</caption>
function onMousePressEvent(event) {
    var pickRay = Camera.computePickRay(event.x, event.y);
    var intersection = Entities.findRayIntersection(pickRay);
    if (intersection.intersects) {
        // Switch to independent mode.
        Camera.mode = "independent";
        // Look at the entity that was clicked.
        var properties = Entities.getEntityProperties(intersection.entityID, "position");
        Camera.lookAt(properties.position);
    }
}

Controller.mousePressEvent.connect(onMousePressEvent);

description: Sets the camera to continue looking at the specified position even while the camera moves. Only works if the camera is in independent mode.

params.name: position

The Controller.Hardware.OculusTouch object has properties representing Oculus Rift. The property values are integer IDs, uniquely identifying each output. Read-only. These can be mapped to actions or functions or Controller.Standard items in a {@link RouteObject} mapping.

PropertyTypeDataDescription
Buttons
Anumbernumber"A" button pressed.
Bnumbernumber"B" button pressed.
Xnumbernumber"X" button pressed.
Ynumbernumber"Y" button pressed.
LeftApplicationMenunumbernumberLeft application menu button pressed.
RightApplicationMenunumbernumberRight application menu button pressed.
Sticks
LXnumbernumberLeft stick x-axis scale.
LYnumbernumberLeft stick y-axis scale.
RXnumbernumberRight stick x-axis scale.
RYnumbernumberRight stick y-axis scale.
LSnumbernumberLeft stick button pressed.
RSnumbernumberRight stick button pressed.
LSTouchnumbernumberLeft stick is touched.
RSTouchnumbernumberRight stick is touched.
Triggers
LTnumbernumberLeft trigger scale.
RTnumbernumberRight trigger scale.
LeftGripnumbernumberLeft grip scale.
RightGripnumbernumberRight grip scale.
Finger Abstractions
LeftPrimaryThumbTouchnumbernumberLeft thumb touching primary thumb button.
LeftSecondaryThumbTouchnumbernumberLeft thumb touching secondary thumb button.
LeftThumbUpnumbernumberLeft thumb not touching primary or secondary thumb buttons.
RightPrimaryThumbTouchnumbernumberRight thumb touching primary thumb button.
RightSecondaryThumbTouchnumbernumberRight thumb touching secondary thumb button.
RightThumbUpnumbernumberRight thumb not touching primary or secondary thumb buttons.
LeftPrimaryIndexTouchnumbernumberLeft index finger is touching primary index finger control.
LeftIndexPointnumbernumberLeft index finger is pointing, not touching primary or secondary index finger controls.
RightPrimaryIndexTouchnumbernumberRight index finger is touching primary index finger control.
RightIndexPointnumbernumberRight index finger is pointing, not touching primary or secondary index finger controls.
Avatar Skeleton
Headnumber{@link Pose}Head pose.
LeftHandnumber{@link Pose}Left hand pose.
RightHandnumber{@link Pose}right hand pose.

description: Triggered when an avatar arrives in the domain.

<caption>Report when an avatar arrives in the domain.</caption>
AvatarManager.avatarAddedEvent.connect(function (sessionID) {

description: Sets joint translations and rotations from raw joint data.
name: setRawJointData

params.description: The raw joint data.
params.name: data

deprecated: This function is deprecated and will be removed.

description:
Sets a specific joint's rotation and position relative to its parent, in model coordinates.

Warning: These coordinates are not necessarily in meters.

Setting joint data completely overrides/replaces all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics, but just for the specified joint. So for example, if you were to procedurally manipulate the finger joints, the avatar's hand and head would still do inverse kinematics properly. However, as soon as you start to manipulate joints in the inverse kinematics chain, the inverse kinematics might not function as you expect. For example, if you set the rotation of the elbow, the hand inverse kinematics position won't end up in the right place.
name: setJointData

params.description: The index of the joint.
params.name: index

params.description: The rotation of the joint relative to its parent.
params.name: rotation

params.description: The translation of the joint relative to its parent, in model coordinates.
params.name: translation

examples:
Set your avatar to it's default T-pose for a while.
// Set all joint translations and rotations to defaults. var i, length, rotation, translation; for (i = 0, length = MyAvatar.getJointNames().length; i < length; i++) { rotation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointRotation(i); translation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointTranslation(i); MyAvatar.setJointData(i, rotation, translation); } // Restore your avatar's motion after 5s. Script.setTimeout(function () { MyAvatar.clearJointsData(); }, 5000); // Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description:
Sets a specific joint's rotation relative to its parent.

Setting joint data completely overrides/replaces all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics, but just for the specified joint. So for example, if you were to procedurally manipulate the finger joints, the avatar's hand and head would still do inverse kinematics properly. However, as soon as you start to manipulate joints in the inverse kinematics chain, the inverse kinematics might not function as you expect. For example, if you set the rotation of the elbow, the hand inverse kinematics position won't end up in the right place.
name: setJointRotation

params.description: The name of the joint.
params.name: name

params.description: The rotation of the joint relative to its parent.
params.name: rotation

examples:
Set your avatar to its default T-pose then rotate its right arm.
// Set all joint translations and rotations to defaults. var i, length, rotation, translation; for (i = 0, length = MyAvatar.getJointNames().length; i < length; i++) { rotation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointRotation(i); translation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointTranslation(i); MyAvatar.setJointData(i, rotation, translation); } // Rotate the right arm. var newArmRotation = { x: 0.47, y: 0.22, z: -0.02, w: 0.87 }; MyAvatar.setJointRotation("RightArm", newArmRotation); // Restore your avatar's motion after 5s. Script.setTimeout(function () { MyAvatar.clearJointsData(); }, 5000); // Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

Sets a specific joint's translation relative to its parent, in model coordinates.

Warning: These coordinates are not necessarily in meters.

Setting joint data completely overrides/replaces all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics, but just for the specified joint. So for example, if you were to procedurally manipulate the finger joints, the avatar's hand and head would still do inverse kinematics properly. However, as soon as you start to manipulate joints in the inverse kinematics chain, the inverse kinematics might not function as you expect. For example, if you set the rotation of the elbow, the hand inverse kinematics position won't end up in the right place.
name: setJointTranslation

params.description: The index of the joint.
params.name: index

params.description: The translation of the joint relative to its parent, in model coordinates.
params.name: translation

description:
Sets a specific joint's translation relative to its parent, in model coordinates.

Warning: These coordinates are not necessarily in meters.

Setting joint data completely overrides/replaces all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics, but just for the specified joint. So for example, if you were to procedurally manipulate the finger joints, the avatar's hand and head would still do inverse kinematics properly. However, as soon as you start to manipulate joints in the inverse kinematics chain, the inverse kinematics might not function as you expect. For example, if you set the rotation of the elbow, the hand inverse kinematics position won't end up in the right place.
name: setJointTranslation

params.description: The name of the joint.
params.name: name

params.description: The translation of the joint relative to its parent, in model coordinates.
params.name: translation

examples:
Stretch your avatar's neck. Depending on the avatar you are using, you will either see a gap between the head and body or you will see the neck stretched.
// Stretch your avatar's neck. MyAvatar.setJointTranslation("Neck", Vec3.multiply(2, MyAvatar.getJointTranslation("Neck"))); // Restore your avatar's neck after 5s. Script.setTimeout(function () { MyAvatar.clearJointData("Neck"); }, 5000); // Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description:
Clears joint translations and rotations set by script for a specific joint. This restores all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics for that joint.

Note: This is slightly faster than the function variation that specifies the joint name.
name: clearJointData

params.description: The index of the joint.
params.name: index

description:
Clears joint translations and rotations set by script for a specific joint. This restores all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics for that joint.

Note: This is slightly slower than the function variation that specifies the joint index.
name: clearJointData

params.description: The name of the joint.
params.name: name

examples:
<caption>Offset and restore the position of your avatar's head.</caption>
// Stretch your avatar's neck.
MyAvatar.setJointTranslation("Neck", Vec3.multiply(2, MyAvatar.getJointTranslation("Neck")));

// Restore your avatar's neck after 5s.
Script.setTimeout(function () {
    MyAvatar.clearJointData("Neck");
}, 5000);

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description:
Sets the rotations of all joints in the current avatar. Each joint's rotation is relative to its parent joint.

Setting joint data completely overrides/replaces all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics, but just for the specified joint. So for example, if you were to procedurally manipulate the finger joints, the avatar's hand and head would still do inverse kinematics properly. However, as soon as you start to manipulate joints in the inverse kinematics chain, the inverse kinematics might not function as you expect. For example, if you set the rotation of the elbow, the hand inverse kinematics position won't end up in the right place.
name: setJointRotations

params.description: The rotations for all joints in the avatar. The values are in the same order as the array returned by {@link MyAvatar.getJointNames}, or {@link Avatar.getJointNames} if using the Avatar API.
params.name: jointRotations

examples:
Set your avatar to its default T-pose then rotate its right arm.
// Set all joint translations and rotations to defaults. var i, length, rotation, translation; for (i = 0, length = MyAvatar.getJointNames().length; i < length; i++) { rotation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointRotation(i); translation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointTranslation(i); MyAvatar.setJointData(i, rotation, translation); } // Get all join rotations. var jointRotations = MyAvatar.getJointRotations(); // Update the rotation of the right arm in the array. jointRotations[MyAvatar.getJointIndex("RightArm")] = { x: 0.47, y: 0.22, z: -0.02, w: 0.87 }; // Update all joint rotations. MyAvatar.setJointRotations(jointRotations); // Restore your avatar's motion after 5s. Script.setTimeout(function () { MyAvatar.clearJointsData(); }, 5000); // Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description:
Sets the translations of all joints in the current avatar. Each joint's translation is relative to its parent joint, in model coordinates.

Warning: These coordinates are not necessarily in meters.

Setting joint data completely overrides/replaces all motion from the default animation system including inverse kinematics, but just for the specified joint. So for example, if you were to procedurally manipulate the finger joints, the avatar's hand and head would still do inverse kinematics properly. However, as soon as you start to manipulate joints in the inverse kinematics chain, the inverse kinematics might not function as you expect. For example, if you set the rotation of the elbow, the hand inverse kinematics position won't end up in the right place.
name: setJointTranslations

params.description: The translations for all joints in the avatar, in model coordinates. The values are in the same order as the array returned by {@link MyAvatar.getJointNames}, or {@link Avatar.getJointNames} if using the Avatar API.
params.name: translations

description:
Clears all joint translations and rotations that have been set by script. This restores all motion from the default 
animation system including inverse kinematics for all joints.
name: clearJointsData
examples:
<caption>Set your avatar to it's default T-pose for a while.</caption>
// Set all joint translations and rotations to defaults.
var i, length, rotation, translation;
for (i = 0, length = MyAvatar.getJointNames().length; i < length; i++) {
    rotation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointRotation(i);
    translation = MyAvatar.getDefaultJointTranslation(i);
    MyAvatar.setJointData(i, rotation, translation);
}

// Restore your avatar's motion after 5s.
Script.setTimeout(function () {
    MyAvatar.clearJointsData();
}, 5000);

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description:
Sets the value of a blendshape to animate your avatar's face. To enable other users to see the resulting animation of 
your avatar's face, use {@link Avatar.setForceFaceTrackerConnected} or {@link MyAvatar.setForceFaceTrackerConnected}.
name: setBlendshape

params.description:
The name of the blendshape, per the 
    {@link https://docs.highfidelity.com/create/avatars/avatar-standards.html#blendshapes Avatar Standards}.
params.name: name

params.description: A value between 0.0 and 1.0.
params.name: value

examples:
<caption>Open your avatar's mouth wide.</caption>
MyAvatar.setForceFaceTrackerConnected(true);
MyAvatar.setBlendshape("JawOpen", 1.0);

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

for (var i = 0; i < attachments.length; i++) {
    print(attachments[i].modelURL);
}

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description: Sets all models currently attached to your avatar. For example, if you retrieve attachment data using {@link MyAvatar.getAttachmentData} or {@link Avatar.getAttachmentData}, make changes to it, and then want to update your avatar's attachments per the changed data. You can also remove all attachments by using setting attachmentData to null.
name: setAttachmentData

params.description: The attachment data defining the models to have attached to your avatar. Use null to remove all attachments.
params.name: attachmentData

deprecated: This function is deprecated and will be removed. Use avatar entities instead.
examples:
<caption>Remove a hat attachment if your avatar is wearing it.</caption>
var hatURL = "https://s3.amazonaws.com/hifi-public/tony/cowboy-hat.fbx";
var attachments = MyAvatar.getAttachmentData();

for (var i = 0; i < attachments.length; i++) {
    if (attachments[i].modelURL === hatURL) {
        attachments.splice(i, 1);
        MyAvatar.setAttachmentData(attachments);
        break;
    }
 }

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace all occurrences of "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description:
Attaches a model to your avatar. For example, you can give your avatar a hat to wear, a guitar to hold, or a surfboard to stand on.

Note: Attached models are models only; they are not entities and can not be manipulated using the {@link Entities} API. Nor can you use this function to attach an entity (such as a sphere or a box) to your avatar.
name: attach

params.description: The URL of the model to attach. Models can be .FBX or .OBJ format.
params.name: modelURL

params.description:
The name of the avatar joint (see {@link MyAvatar.getJointNames} or {@link Avatar.getJointNames}) to attach the model 
    to.
params.name: jointName

params.description: The offset to apply to the model relative to the joint position.
params.name: translation

params.description: The rotation to apply to the model relative to the joint orientation.
params.name: rotation

params.description: The scale to apply to the model.
params.name: scale

params.description:
If the model has a skeleton, set this to true so that the bones of the attached model's skeleton are rotated to fit the avatar's current pose. isSoft is used, for example, to have clothing that moves with the avatar.
If true, the translation, rotation, and scale parameters are ignored.
params.name: isSoft

params.description: If true then more than one copy of any particular model may be attached to the same joint; if false then the same model cannot be attached to the same joint.
params.name: allowDuplicates

params.description: Not used.
params.name: useSaved

deprecated: This function is deprecated and will be removed. Use avatar entities instead.
examples:
<caption>Attach a cowboy hat to your avatar's head.</caption>
var attachment = {
    modelURL: "https://s3.amazonaws.com/hifi-public/tony/cowboy-hat.fbx",
    jointName: "Head",
    translation: {"x": 0, "y": 0.25, "z": 0},
    rotation: {"x": 0, "y": 0, "z": 0, "w": 1},
    scale: 1,
    isSoft: false
};

 MyAvatar.attach(attachment.modelURL,
                 attachment.jointName,
                 attachment.translation,
                 attachment.rotation,
                 attachment.scale,
                 attachment.isSoft);

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

params.name: modelURL

params.description: The name of the joint to detach the model from. If "", then the most recently attached model is removed from which ever joint it was attached to.
params.name: jointName

deprecated: This function is deprecated and will be removed. Use avatar entities instead.

description: Detaches all instances of a particular model from either a specific joint or all joints.

params.name: modelURL

params.description: The name of the joint to detach the model from. If "", then the model is detached from all joints.
params.name: jointName

description: Gets the transform from the user's real world to the avatar's size, orientation, and position in the virtual world.
name: getSensorToWorldMatrix

returns.description:
The scale, rotation, and translation transform from the user's real world to the avatar's size, 
    orientation, and position in the virtual world.

examples:
<caption>Report the sensor to world matrix.</caption>
var sensorToWorldMatrix = MyAvatar.getSensorToWorldMatrix();
print("Sensor to woprld matrix: " + JSON.stringify(sensorToWorldMatrix));
print("Rotation: " + JSON.stringify(Mat4.extractRotation(sensorToWorldMatrix)));
print("Translation: " + JSON.stringify(Mat4.extractTranslation(sensorToWorldMatrix)));
print("Scale: " + JSON.stringify(Mat4.extractScale(sensorToWorldMatrix)));

// Note: If using from the Avatar API, replace "MyAvatar" with "Avatar".

description: Gets the scale that transforms dimensions in the user's real world to the avatar's size in the virtual world.
name: getSensorToWorldScale

returns.description:
The scale that transforms dimensions in the user's real world to the avatar's size in the virtual 
    world.

description: Gets the rotation and translation of the left hand controller relative to the avatar.

params.description: Delta size.

deprecated: This function is deprecated and will be removed.

description: Prefetches a resource.
name: prefetch

params.description: The URL of the resource to prefetch.
params.name: url

returns.description: A resource object.

examples:
<caption>Prefetch a resource and wait until it has loaded.</caption>
// Replace AnimationCache with ModelCache, SoundCache, or TextureCache as appropriate.
// TextureCache has its own version of this function.

var resourceURL = "https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/hifi-content/clement/production/animations/sitting_idle.fbx";
var resourceObject = AnimationCache.prefetch(resourceURL);

function checkIfResourceLoaded(state) {
    if (state === Resource.State.FINISHED) {
        print("Resource loaded and ready.");
    } else if (state === Resource.State.FAILED) {
        print("Resource not loaded.");
    }
}

// Resource may have already been loaded.
print("Resource state: " + resourceObject.state);
checkIfResourceLoaded(resourceObject.state);

// Resource may still be loading.
resourceObject.stateChanged.connect(function (state) {
    print("Resource state changed to: " + state);
    checkIfResourceLoaded(state);
});

description: Triggered when the cache content has changed.
name: dirty
